message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<Vertex> it = adjList[i].iterator(); it.hasNext();) {
  Vertex node = it.next();
  if (it.hasNext()) {
    System.out.println("====="+node.name);
    if(node.color.equals("WHITE")) {
      node.color = "GRAY";
      node.distance = u.distance + 1;
      node.pre = u;
      Q.add(node);
    }
  }
}
<<<explanation>>>: Yes, it is possible to skip the first value while using an iterator. You can use the hasNext() method to check if there is a next element in the iterator. If there is, you can perform the desired operations on the element. In your case, you can add an if statement to check if it.hasNext() before printing the value and performing other operations on the node.
